history.content:
It's not too late to join EE121!

The first discussion is this Friday 1-2pm in 521 Cory , and I will briefly cover where the class is going to those of you who joined late.

This is a great class and is not offered very frequently -- you should consider taking it.

It's also a very small class (< 20), so there will be a lot of interaction and flexibility.

It will start with classical communication (how to transmit bits reliably over a noisy channel?) and then cover more modern topics like network coding and distributed storage. By the end you will be able to understand recent research developments in the area.

There will be two group projects.


The first project will be: Create a system for robustly transferring a file between two laptops, using only audio (speakers and microphone). Just like old dial-up modems. (This will involve many things such as modulation, equalization, error-correcting codes, etc)

Topics covered include: communication over binary and gaussian channels, erasure and error-correcting codes, linear codes & decoding algorithms, modulation and wireless channels, network coding, distributed storage codes, and much more.

Prereqs: Probability and linear systems at the level of CS70, EE126, and (EE20 or EE16B).
history.subject: Consider EE121! (Digital Communication)
